data.title: Actress and radio presenter Jill Halfpenny chats auditions, exercise and early starts
data.meta_description: ACTRESS Jill Halfpenny talks about getting over audition angst and her addiction to Ru Paul's Drag Race.
data.text:
AS I get older, I appreciate mornings more.

When I was younger and woke at 6am, I’d be really annoyed and think it was such a waste, but now I get excited about how much I can get done.

I’ve worked out the exact time I need to get my son Harvey, 10, up and out for school, so we have an agreement that I don’t wake him any earlier, but he has to be like a robot and just get ready right away.

My body wouldn’t feel like mine if I didn’t exercise. It’s nothing to do with weight, it’s about strength and vitality.

If I’m not working, I’ll go to an hour-long class at 9.30am – anything from conditioning or spin to barre or yoga. The body needs to be kept flexible.

I don’t want to be that old lady who breaks a hip when she falls over.

Afterwards I eat breakfast. I might have yoghurt with fruit and honey or toast with scrambled egg, or I might wander to my local cafe and get pancakes.

I don’t think any actor likes auditions. I don’t know how many job interviews the average person has in a lifetime, but actors have thousands.

If I have an audition coming up, I’ll learn lines and prepare the scene for a couple of hours after breakfast. I used to take rejection to heart and presume I wasn’t good enough, but now I know it could be that I’m the wrong height or have the wrong hair colour.

It takes a strong person to put themselves through that. If you don’t gain perspective, you can become bitter or anxious.

After my lines, I’ll do life admin and have a snack like chia pudding or cheese on toast. Then I collect Harvey from school at 3pm.

Shopping for groceries is the most boring thing in the world.

If I were rich, I’d have a chef, but I’ve signed up to a food delivery company that sends ingredients and recipe cards for delicious meals.

I like that everything is measured out and it makes me prepare dishes I wouldn’t normally dare to.

Yesterday we had chicken with harissa, barley, coriander, cherry tomatoes and green beans with figs.

Harvey and I will sit down and watch RuPaul’s Drag Race – we’re addicted – then eat at around 6pm.

I don’t have a night routine. Harvey goes to bed at 7.30pm and I might read or listen to an audiobook as I fall asleep.

I love therapeutic books. I can’t learn enough about the brain and the way people are conditioned.

At the minute, I’m reading Dark Nights Of The Soul: A Guide To Finding Your Way Through Life’s Ordeals by Thomas Moore.

I’m fascinated by what makes people tick.

Some days I might have a theatre show in the evenings, so I won’t get home until 11pm.

Either way I try not to go to sleep too late as I like getting up early.
